questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy; the X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drug is not used for the management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Vincristine

Explanation:

  • • Options A. Cyclophosphamide: Explanation
  • • Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation : Methotrexate is used to treat LCH by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.
  • • Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation
  • • Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation : Vinblastine is commonly used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children, by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells.
  • • Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation
  • • Options D. Vincristine: Explanation : Vincristine is not recommended for LCH. Other chemotherapy drugs like vinblastine are preferred for this condition.
  • • Options D. Vincristine: Explanation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is treated with various chemotherapy drugs, but vincristine is not typically used for this condition. Vinblastine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and other drugs are preferred for the management of LCH.

questions.text: What is the sequence of performing a Thomas test?(INICET NOV 2021) Passive flexion of affected hip Overcorrection on the normal side Measure the flexion angle Checking for lumbar lordosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) IV, II, I, III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of performing the Thomas test is:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of performing the Thomas test is:
  • ➤ Checking for lumbar lordosis
  • ➤ ↓
  • ➤ Overcorrection on the normal side
  • ➤ ↓
  • ➤ Passive flexion of affected hip
  • ➤ ↓
  • ➤ Measure the flexion angle

questions.text: Which form of vitiligo is initially progressive and later becomes stable and non-progressive? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Segmental

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Segmental vitiligo is characterized by its initial rapid progression confined to a segmental area, followed by stabilization and lack of further progression, distinguishing it from other forms of vitiligo that can remain progressive.

questions.text: A new drug is tested in clinical trials and was found to have a therapeutic index of 20. Which of the following statements best describes the therapeutic index of the drug? (Fmge Jan 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the extent of absorption of the drug and is calculated from the area under curve of the plasma concentration vs time graph

options.label: B
options.text: It represents distribution of the drug in different tissues and is calculated by dividing the plasma concentration with the amount of drug given

options.label: C
options.text: It represents the duration of action of the drug and is calculated from the half-life of the drug

options.label: D
options.text: It represents margin of safety of a drug and is calculated as a ratio of LD50 to ED50

questions.correct_answer: D. It represents margin of safety of a drug and is calculated as a ratio of LD50 to ED50
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. It represents margin of safety of a drug and is calculated as a ratio of LD50 to ED50

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The therapeutic index (TI) is a crucial parameter that represents the margin of safety for a drug. It is calculated as the ratio of LD50 to ED50, indicating the range between an effective dose and a potentially lethal dose. A higher TI indicates a safer drug with a wider margin of safety.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic acts on the site X shown in the figure? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hydrochlorothiazide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that acts on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) by inhibiting the Na-Cl symporter, thereby reducing sodium reabsorption and promoting diuresis. This makes it effective for treating conditions such as hypertension and edema. Other diuretics like furosemide, spironolactone, and acetazolamide act on different parts of the nephron and have distinct mechanisms of action.

questions.text: Match the following teratogenic drugs with their teratogenic effects: ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The teratogenic effects of certain drugs is crucial for managing medication use during pregnancy. Lithium can cause Ebstein’s anomaly, Warfarin is associated with saddle nose and growth retardation, Thalidomide causes limb malformations, and Chloramphenicol can lead to Grey Baby Syndrome.

questions.text: By which cell of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Naive B cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells, distinguishing it from other B-cell and T-cell malignancies.

questions.text: A primigravida is in labour. Her per-vaginal examination revealed a posterior cervix with 5 cm cervical length, 1 cm dilatation, soft consistency, and head at -1 station. Calculate the modified Bishop score? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bishop Score
  • • Bishop Score
  • • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor. A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor. The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm). The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are: Cervical Dilatation Cervical length Cervical consistency Cervical Position Station of the presenting part
  • • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor.
  • • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor.
  • • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm).
  • • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are: Cervical Dilatation Cervical length Cervical consistency Cervical Position Station of the presenting part
  • • Cervical Dilatation Cervical length Cervical consistency Cervical Position Station of the presenting part
  • • Cervical Dilatation
  • • Cervical length
  • • Cervical consistency
  • • Cervical Position
  • • Station of the presenting part
  • • Easy to remember Mnemonic
  • • Easy to remember Mnemonic
  • • B – Bishop
  • • I – Effacement
  • • S – Station of presenting part
  • • H – Hard/ soft (consistency)
  • • O – Os dilatation (cervical dilatation)
  • • P – Position of the cervix
  • • The scoring is as shown in the table. Each component is scored from 0 to 3 The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0 A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor.
  • • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Modified Bishop score is used to assess the cervix's favorability for induction, and a score of 5 in this context would be based on specific factors.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: A researcher is comparing the means of three different groups with non-normally distributed data and small sample sizes. Which of the following tests is best suited for analyzing this non-parametric data? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Friedman test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Choose the Friedman test when you need to compare the means of three or more related groups, and the data is not normally distributed, ensuring accurate and reliable statistical analysis in non-parametric settings.
  • ➤ Choose the Friedman test when you need to compare the means of three or more related groups, and the data is not normally distributed, ensuring accurate and reliable statistical analysis in non-parametric settings.

questions.text: In a gunshot case, blackening is noted surrounding a firearm entry wound. Blackening occurs mainly due to: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D. Black smoke particles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The presence of blackening, soot, and unburnt gunpowder at a gunshot entry wound provides crucial information about the distance and angle of the shot.

questions.text: A 35-year-old car racer is brought to the emergency department after a car accident on the race track. He is unconscious and is immediately put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding sirtuins? (INICET NOV 2022) Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism. Promotes genes that increase longevity. They are of 7 types. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sirtuins are a family of seven histone deacetylases involved in increasing insulin sensitivity, glucose metabolism, promoting genes associated with longevity, and playing a significant role in various cellular processes.
  • ➤ Sirtuins

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Paratonsillar vein

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the case described, the patient likely underwent surgery for a peritonsillar abscess (aka Quinsy), a complication arising from tonsillitis. This condition can lead to significant swelling in the throat and difficulty swallowing. Post-operative bleeding in such cases, especially the continuous type noted as soaking through gauze, is most commonly associated with venous sources rather than arterial.
  • • The given image is a cadaveric specimen with an arrow pointing to the tonsillar fossa. The paratonsillar / external palatine vein is the typical site of venous origin for post-tonsillectomy bleeding.
  • • The paratonsillar vein, which is closely associated with the tonsillar bed and provides significant venous drainage for the tonsil, is the likely source of this bleeding. Venous bleeding tends to be continuous and can be persistent if the vein is not adequately secured during surgery.
  • • Torrential hemorrhage can be due to injury to an aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of the facial artery.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery : The tonsils receive blood supply primarily from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery. Injury to this artery during tonsillar surgery can cause bleeding, but the bleeding is usually brisk and bright red, and the artery would likely be cauterized or ligated during surgery to prevent such bleeding.
  • • Option A.
  • • Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
  • • Option B . Ascending pharyngeal artery : It's a branch of the external carotid artery and supplies the pharynx, soft palate, and the tympanic cavity. While this artery does provide blood supply to the pharyngeal region, it's not as intimately associated with the tonsillar region as the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.
  • • Option B
  • • Ascending pharyngeal artery
  • • Option D . Retromandibular vein : The retromandibular vein is formed by the union of the superficial temporal vein and the maxillary vein in the parotid gland. It's located further away from the tonsillar region, and it's unlikely to be injured during procedures involving the tonsils.
  • • Option D
  • • Retromandibular vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blood supply of the tonsils:
  • ➤ Blood supply of the tonsils:
  • ➤ Arterial supply:
  • ➤ Arterial supply:
  • ➤ The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply. Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.
  • ➤ The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply.
  • ➤ Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.
  • ➤ Venous supply:
  • ➤ Venous supply:
  • ➤ Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.
  • ➤ Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.
  • ➤ Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:
  • ➤ Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:
  • ➤ 1. Primary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ 1. Primary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels. Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • ➤ Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
  • ➤ Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • ➤ 2. Reactionary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ 2. Reactionary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ It occurs within 24 hours of surgery. It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal. It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor. If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.
  • ➤ It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
  • ➤ It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal.
  • ➤ It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
  • ➤ If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.
  • ➤ 3. Secondary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ 3. Secondary hemorrhage:
  • ➤ It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days). It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.
  • ➤ It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days).
  • ➤ It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
  • ➤ The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

questions.text: Calculate the Downe score of a newborn who has cyanosis which improves on giving oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, air entry markedly decreased, RR 40 per minute? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. A score of 6 in this case indicates moderate respiratory distress, characterized by cyanosis that improves with oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, markedly decreased air entry, and a normal respiratory rate.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a young man who has presented with painful lesions, as depicted in the image below? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Herpes Zoster

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ability to recognize Herpes Zoster by its characteristic painful, vesicular rash in a unilateral dermatomal distribution.
  • ➤ Herpes Zoster
  • ➤ painful, vesicular
  • ➤ unilateral dermatomal
  • ➤ Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28, 109.36, 128.2,
  • ➤ Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28, 109.36, 128.2,
  • ➤ Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106
  • ➤ Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

questions.text: Which of the following is considered ineffective in the prevention of COVID-19? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ivermectin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ivermectin, despite being widely discussed during the pandemic, has not been proven effective in preventing COVID-19 infection, unlike established preventive measures such as masks, vaccines, and proper cough etiquette.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked green in the image below? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Opponens pollicis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The palmar aspect of the first metacarpal is the area marked in the image. At this location, the opponens pollicis muscle inserts.
  • • Opponens pollicis: Origin: Tubercle of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal. Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.
  • • Opponens pollicis:
  • • Opponens pollicis:
  • • Origin: Tubercle of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • • Origin:
  • • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • • Insertion:
  • • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.
  • • Action:
  • • The image below shows various intrinsic muscles of the hand.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . Abductor Pollicis Longus: Abductor pollicis longus is not directly attached to the first metacarpal. It originates from the posterior surface of the ulna and radius and inserts into the base of the first metacarpal bone. Its primary action is to abduct the thumb away from the palm.
  • • Option A
  • • Abductor Pollicis Longus:
  • • Option B. Palmar Interossei: The palmar interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones in the palm of the hand. They are responsible for adducting the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They are not directly attached to the first metacarpal.
  • • Option B.
  • • Palmar Interossei:
  • • Option D . Flexor Pollicis Brevis: The flexor pollicis brevis muscle has two heads: the superficial head and the deep head. The superficial head originates from the flexor retinaculum, while the deep head originates from the trapezoid and capitate bones.
  • • Option D
  • • Flexor Pollicis Brevis:
  • • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone. The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone.
  • • The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the tubercles of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone. The primary action of the opponens pollicis is to oppose the thumb, allowing for the grasping and pinching movements of the thumb.
  • ➤ The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the tubercles of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone.
  • ➤ The primary action of the opponens pollicis is to oppose the thumb, allowing for the grasping and pinching movements of the thumb.

questions.text: What is the most common site of abdominal tuberculosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ileocecal junction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common site of abdominal tuberculosis is the ileocecal junction, particularly near the terminal ileum. This region's lymphoid tissue creates a favorable environment for Mycobacterium tuberculosis to proliferate.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the central line insertion below the marked bone? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Arterial puncture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The bone indicated in the image above is the left clavicle. An arterial puncture is the most common complication of a central line insertion below this bone.
  • • Complications of central vein catheterization are - Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication. Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle. Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization. Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common. Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords. Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins. Infections
  • • Complications of central vein catheterization are - Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication. Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle. Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization. Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common. Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords. Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins. Infections
  • • Complications of central vein catheterization are -
  • • Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication. Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle. Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization. Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common. Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords. Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins. Infections
  • • Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication.
  • • Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
  • • Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization.
  • • Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
  • • Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
  • • Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins.
  • • Infections
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B . Thrombophlebitis : Thrombophlebitis refers to inflammation of a vein associated with clot formation. While thrombophlebitis can occur following any central line placement, it's more commonly associated with peripheral IV lines. However, central venous catheters are more commonly associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is the formation of a blood clot inside the larger, deeper veins.
  • • Option B
  • • Thrombophlebitis
  • • Option C. Empyema : Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity. While empyema itself is not a direct complication of central line placement, pneumothorax or hemothorax (air or blood in the pleural space, respectively) caused by central line placement can lead to infection and subsequently empyema if not recognized and treated.
  • • Option C.
  • • Empyema
  • • Option D . Chylothorax : Chylothorax is the accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the pleural space. This can happen if the thoracic duct is damaged. The thoracic duct is a major lymphatic vessel that runs in the thorax but is not typically at risk with subclavian line placement. Chylothorax would be more of a concern with procedures that are done in close proximity to the thoracic duct, like surgeries or interventions in the mediastinum or around the esophagus.
  • • Option D
  • • Chylothorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arterial puncture is one of the most common complications associated with the subclavian approach for central venous catheter placement. The subclavian artery lies directly beneath the vein, so inadvertent puncture of the artery can occur if the needle is advanced too deeply or at an incorrect angle. Accidental puncture of the subclavian artery can lead to complications such as hematoma, hemothorax, and can also be problematic if not recognized because threading a catheter into the arterial system can have catastrophic consequences.
  • ➤ Arterial puncture

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnostic criteria for DKA include hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Potassium levels, while important to monitor and manage in DKA, are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.explanation: Ans. A. Cavus

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypomenorrhea

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in casualty. An elderly 60-year-old man is brought to you with complaints of chest pain. He has tested positive for COVID. Which of the following features will prompt you to get this patient admitted to dedicated COVID health centre? (INICET NOV 2020) A. Respiratory rate of 25/min B. SpO2 93% C. Multiple comorbidities D. Age
questions.correct_answer: B. A, B, C & D only
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A, B, C & D only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When evaluating a COVID-19 patient for hospital admission, consider clinical signs of respiratory distress, overall oxygen saturation, presence of comorbidities, and age due to their significant impacts on disease severity and outcome.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with an arrow: ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pulmonary trunk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel located anterior to the aorta, bifurcating into the right and left pulmonary arteries, and is the structure identified by the arrow in the cross-sectional image of the thorax.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding immune surveillance? ( AIIMS NOV 2020)

options.label: A

options.label: C

Ans. A) Anti CTLA 4 Ab is a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-CTLA-4 antibodies like Ipilimumab are a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers, enhancing the anti-tumor immune response by blocking inhibitory signals to T cells.

questions.text: In given image, nucleus of marked nerve is related to (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cervical spinal segment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The phrenic nerve originates from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5, and is essential for diaphragm movement and breathing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is found to have a fibroid of 14 weeks size. She has no specific symptoms. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)

options.label: C
options.text: No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

questions.correct_answer: C. No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the case of an asymptomatic fibroid, intervention is generally not required regardless of the size. The management approach is typically conservative, involving observation and regular monitoring.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Asymptomatic Fibroids: Fibroids that do not cause symptoms do not require immediate intervention. Instead, they can be observed with yearly ultrasounds or reviewed earlier if symptoms develop. Common Symptoms of Fibroids: These include heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, pressure symptoms, and the presence of an abdominal mass. Management of Symptomatic Fibroids: Depending on the patient's age, size of the fibroid, number, and location, symptomatic fibroids may be considered for myomectomy or hysterectomy.
  • • Asymptomatic Fibroids: Fibroids that do not cause symptoms do not require immediate intervention. Instead, they can be observed with yearly ultrasounds or reviewed earlier if symptoms develop.
  • • Asymptomatic Fibroids:
  • • Common Symptoms of Fibroids: These include heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, pressure symptoms, and the presence of an abdominal mass.
  • • Common Symptoms of Fibroids:
  • • Management of Symptomatic Fibroids: Depending on the patient's age, size of the fibroid, number, and location, symptomatic fibroids may be considered for myomectomy or hysterectomy.
  • • Management of Symptomatic Fibroids:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Hysterectomy: This is a major surgical procedure and is typically reserved for symptomatic fibroids or when other treatment options have failed or are not suitable.
  • • Option A. Hysterectomy:
  • • Option B. Myomectomy: Myomectomy is a surgical procedure to remove fibroids and is considered for symptomatic patients who wish to preserve their uterus.
  • • Option B. Myomectomy:
  • • Option D. Medical management: Medical management is used to manage symptoms and is not necessary for asymptomatic fibroids.
  • • Option D. Medical management:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In asymptomatic patients with fibroids, intervention is generally not required. Observation and regular monitoring are appropriate unless symptoms develop, in which case, further management options such as myomectomy or hysterectomy may be considered.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg207
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg207

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient with fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later he presents with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Amoxicillin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amoxicillin, an aminopenicillin antibiotic, is commonly associated with allergic reactions, including maculopapular rashes. This is a well-known side effect of penicillin antibiotics. Prednisolone, salbutamol, and fexofenadine are less likely to cause such reactions, and in the case of prednisolone and fexofenadine, they are actually used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

questions.text: What among the following can be employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hall-Wellner Band

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hall-Wellner band is employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve, providing a visual representation of the variability and confidence in the survival estimates.
  • ➤ The Hall-Wellner band is employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve, providing a visual representation of the variability and confidence in the survival estimates.

questions.text: An old man presents with dyspnea and swelling of his feet. On examination, rales are heard and he is found to have an enlarged heart on chest x-ray. Which of the following will delay the progression?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Captopril

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, has been shown to improve survival and delay the progression of heart failure. ACE inhibitors like Captopril work by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, leading to vasodilation and reduced workload on the heart. This class of drugs is considered a cornerstone in the management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HF-REF). The benefits of ACE inhibitors in heart failure are well-documented, including the 1992 study on Enalapril, which demonstrated its effectiveness as a gold standard treatment.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Furosemide: A loop diuretic, Furosemide is effective in reducing symptoms of congestion and decreasing heart failure hospitalization rates but does not improve survival or delay disease progression.
  • • Option A. Furosemide:
  • • Option B. Carvedilol: While Carvedilol, a non-selective beta-blocker, has mortality benefits and improves survival in heart failure patients, it is not preferred over ACE inhibitors as the first choice for delaying heart failure progression.
  • • Option B. Carvedilol:
  • • Option C. Digoxin: This medication can reduce symptoms and heart failure hospitalizations to some extent, particularly in advanced heart failure, but it does not delay disease progression or improve survival, as evidenced by trials like the DIG trial.
  • • Option C. Digoxin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors, such as Captopril, are essential in delaying the progression of heart failure and improving survival.

questions.text: The table below gives the AUC of drug B alone and that of drug B when combined with another drug A. If the p value is <0.01, then which of the following statements is true? (INICET 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Drug A decreases intestinal absorption of Drug B

options.label: B
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿ Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of Drug B

options.label: C
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿Drug A increases the metabolism of Drug B

options.label: D
options.text: Drug A increases renal elimination of Drug B

questions.correct_answer: B. ﻿﻿﻿ Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of Drug B
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of Drug B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The increase in the AUC of Drug B when combined with Drug A, with a statistically significant p value, indicates that Drug A reduces the first pass metabolism of Drug B, thereby increasing its bioavailability.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023) 1.Hypokalemia 2.Hypochloremia 3.Metabolic alkalosis 4.Respiratory alkalosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe vomiting and diarrhea typically cause hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: What condition can lead to the characteristic waveform on capnography displayed by a patient under general anesthesia as observed on the ET CO2 monitor? ( INICET May 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bronchospasm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm is due to anaphylaxis.
  • ➤ Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm is due to anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Countercurrent mechanism is present in which of the following parts of the body?( INICET Nov 2022) 1. Eye 2. Testes 3. Kidney 4. Gut 5. Lungs
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1,2,3,4,5 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The countercurrent mechanism is a biological system found in various organs such as the eye, testes, kidney, gut, and lungs, allowing for efficient exchange and regulation processes.

questions.text: You are a primary care physician seeing a patient for a routine check-up. The patient expresses concern about colon cancer and asks about potential risk factors and preventive measures. You provide the following information: (INICET NOV 2021) Right and left colon cancers can exhibit distinct behaviour. Colon cancer can have hereditary components. Colon cancer risk can be mitigated by metformin. Liver metastases are a common occurrence in colon cancer. Which of the following options is/are true regarding colon cancer:
questions.explanation: Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, and 4

questions.text: During the surgery of breast carcinoma, a frozen section was conducted. Which of the following options is incorrect regarding this procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: To determine sentinel lymph node involvement

options.label: D
options.text: To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

questions.correct_answer: D. To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The analysis of frozen sections can assist in diagnosing nodal metastasis and identifying the involvement of sentinel lymph nodes during surgery. If a positive node is detected during the procedure, the surgeon can proceed with the immediate removal of axillary lymph nodes. Conversely, if the sentinel node shows no signs of tumor involvement, additional axillary dissection can be avoided. In breast-conserving surgeries, frozen sections can aid in assessing tumor margins and ensuring complete removal.
  • ➤ The analysis of frozen sections can assist in diagnosing nodal metastasis and identifying the involvement of sentinel lymph nodes during surgery.
  • ➤ If a positive node is detected during the procedure, the surgeon can proceed with the immediate removal of axillary lymph nodes.
  • ➤ Conversely, if the sentinel node shows no signs of tumor involvement, additional axillary dissection can be avoided.
  • ➤ In breast-conserving surgeries, frozen sections can aid in assessing tumor margins and ensuring complete removal.

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arrhenoblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arrhenoblastoma is a virilizing ovarian tumor known for its androgen production, often leading to masculinizing symptoms in females.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy presents to the outpatient department. His peripheral smear shows the presence of smudge cells. Which of the following additional investigations will you do to arrive at a diagnosis? ( AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient suspected of having Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) , Flow cytometry is the key diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis by identifying the characteristic immunophenotype of CLL cells.
  • ➤ Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)
  • ➤ Flow cytometry
  • ➤ Ref: Robins Pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 1114
  • ➤ Ref: Robins Pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 1114

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is on losartan develops an HbA1c level of 8.1%. Which of the following drugs would you replace losartan with? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Telmisartan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For hypertensive patients with diabetes and elevated HbA1c levels, Telmisartan is the preferred replacement for losartan due to its PPAR-gamma agonistic activity, which helps improve glycemic control.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Chest Xray is the investigation of choice

Upon further evaluation, it was found that he had a bile leak. The surgeon ordered imaging tests to identify the extent of the bile duct injury. The imaging results showed injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak. What would be the Strasberg classification of this injury? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type C

questions.text: A person often feels that his hands are contaminated and he is forced to wash his hands. Recently, he feels this repetitive, distressing thought of repetitive hand washing has begun affecting his performance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Exposure and response prevention

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For OCD, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of CBT, is the evidence-based first-line treatment. It involves exposing patients to their obsessional triggers while refraining from performing their compulsive rituals, gradually reducing the distress elicited by obsessions.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 425.

questions.text: Non-immune hydrops is seen in all, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Human immunodeficiency virus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Non-immune hydrops fetalis is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in at least two fetal compartments, such as ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or skin edema, not caused by maternal alloimmunization. Pathogenesis includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability. These factors can lead to the development of fetal effusions and anasarca (generalized edema). Infectious causes of non-immune hydrops include parvovirus B19, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella, enterovirus, varicella, herpes simplex, coxsackievirus, listeriosis, leptospirosis, Chagas disease, and Lyme disease.
  • • Non-immune hydrops fetalis is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in at least two fetal compartments, such as ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or skin edema, not caused by maternal alloimmunization.
  • • Pathogenesis includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability. These factors can lead to the development of fetal effusions and anasarca (generalized edema).
  • • Infectious causes of non-immune hydrops include parvovirus B19, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella, enterovirus, varicella, herpes simplex, coxsackievirus, listeriosis, leptospirosis, Chagas disease, and Lyme disease.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Herpes simplex virus : This virus can cause non-immune hydrops due to fetal infection leading to systemic inflammation and multiorgan failure.
  • • Option B. Herpes simplex virus
  • • Option C. Syphilis : A congenital infection with syphilis can cause severe fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis.
  • • Option C. Syphilis
  • • Option D. Parvovirus B19 : This virus is a well-known cause of non-immune hydrops due to its predilection for infecting red blood cell precursors, leading to severe fetal anemia and hydrops.
  • • Option D. Parvovirus B19

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is not a cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition page no 926
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition page no 926

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed for Cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. What would be the diagnosis according to the given image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gallbladder polyp

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gallbladder polyps, as seen in the image, are common and typically benign, with the risk of malignancy increasing with polyp size. Accurate identification is crucial for appropriate management.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 79, 1709
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 79, 1709

questions.text: Which of these statements is true regarding perimetry? (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Kinetic perimetry is used in quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma

options.label: B
options.text: In Static perimetry, stimulus intensity is held constant and moved centrally with detection

options.label: C
options.text: Visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it should have the corresponding optic nerve head abnormalities

options.label: D
options.text: Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot

questions.correct_answer: D. Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perimetry is vital for early detection and monitoring of glaucoma. Generalized constriction of isopters and enlargement of the blind spot are key early signs that can indicate the presence of this eye condition.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient undergoes an appendicectomy procedure. Two days later, she complains of severe abdominal pain and is found to have a collection of blood in the abdomen on examination. On exploration, it is discovered that a particular artery should have been ligated during the surgery to prevent this complication. Which of the following arteries should have been ligated during the appendicectomy procedure to prevent postoperative hemorrhage in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ileocolic artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During the removal of the appendix, the inferior branch of the ileocolic artery needs to be ligated at the base of the appendix to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. The appendicular artery typically arises directly from the ileocolic artery and supplies the appendix through multiple small branches. If not ligated, the appendicular artery may cause bleeding complications.

questions.text: All of the following artery demonstrates Windkessel effect except: ( INICET May 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Radial artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ WINDKESSEL VESSELS
  • ➤ WINDKESSEL VESSELS
  • ➤ Large elastic arteries contain Elastin protein → elastic recoil
  • ➤ Ex: - Aorta & large arteries (e.g. Pulmonary Artery, Carotid, Renal artery)
  • ➤ During systole → Ventricle → eject blood → aorta gets stretched During Diastole → Aortic recoil → DBP At old age → Aortic stenosis → elasticity → hardening of aorta → SBP →DBP→PP
  • ➤ During systole → Ventricle → eject blood → aorta gets stretched
  • ➤ During Diastole → Aortic recoil → DBP
  • ➤ At old age → Aortic stenosis → elasticity → hardening of aorta → SBP →DBP→PP

options.label: A

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold, which is an important anatomical detail relevant in breast examinations and surgeries.

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except: ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melanoma is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy, unlike Kaposi's sarcoma, invasive cervical carcinoma, and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
